descriptionModule.briefSummary: Juvenile idiopathic arthritis (JIA) is the most common pediatric rheumatic disease and the most common systemic disorder associated with uveitis in childhood. JIA-associated uveitis (JIA-uveitis) is typically anterior, chronic, bilateral, nongranulomatous, and asymptomatic. Visual outcomes in JIA-uveitis have improved with current screening and treatment options; however, many patients fail to respond or do not achieve long-lasting remission. Baricitinib, an oral selective Janus kinase (JAK)1 and 2 inhibitor, may impact key cytokines implicated in the pathogenesis of JIA-uveitis or ANA-positive uveitis, representing a potential novel treatment option for disease management.
descriptionModule.detailedDescription: This is a multicenter, phase 3 trial conducted using an open-label Bayesian design. The study will enroll at least 20 and up to 40 patients aged 2 to <18 years with active JIA-uveitis or chronic ANA-positive uveitis without systemic features. At least 20 patients who have had an inadequate response or intolerance to methotrexate (MTX-IR), but not biologic disease-modifying antirheumatic drugs (bDMARDs), will be randomized (1:1) to open-label baricitinib or adalimumab. Approximately 20 additional patients who are MTX-IR or bDMARD inadequate responders will receive baricitinib treatment. Patients will be treated with once daily oral baricitinib at a fixed dose by age group (4 mg for patients aged ≥6 to <18 years and 2 mg for patients <6 years) or adalimumab (20 mg for patients weighing <30 kg and 40 mg for patients ≥30 kg) as a subcutaneous injection every 2 weeks. Treatment with stable background conventional synthetic DMARDs, low-dose corticosteroids, and/or nonsteroidal anti-inflammatory drugs is allowed. The primary endpoint is the proportion of patients with response at week 24, defined according to the SUN criteria as a 2-step decrease in the level of inflammation (anterior chamber cells) or decrease to zero through week 24 in the eye most severely affected at baseline. Patients may continue treatment for up to 5 years in an open-label extension. A novel Bayesian design is used to assess the efficacy of baricitinib, including an adalimumab reference arm, in this small patient population with unmet medical need. Two interim analyses will be performed to determine if the study should be stopped for futility when 10 and 20 baricitinib-treated patients have completed 24 weeks of treatment.

primaryOutcomes.measure: Proportion of patients with response at week 24
primaryOutcomes.description: Response is defined according to the SUN criteria as a 2-step decrease in the level of inflammation (anterior chamber cells) or decrease to zero through week 24 in the eye most severely affected at baseline.

secondaryOutcomes.measure: Change in SUN grade of cells in the anterior chamber through week 24 (part A) and through week 284 (part B) in the most severely affected eye
secondaryOutcomes.description: Change in SUN grade of cells in the anterior chamber from baseline

secondaryOutcomes.measure: Change in SUN grade of cells in the anterior chamber through week 24 and week 284 in the less severely affected eye (if applicable)
secondaryOutcomes.description: Change in SUN grade of cells in the anterior chamber from baseline in the less severely affected eye

secondaryOutcomes.measure: Proportion of responders in patients with bilateral uveitis disease at baseline at weeks 24 and 284
secondaryOutcomes.description: Defined according to the SUN criteria as a 2-step decrease in the level of anterior chamber cells in the most severely affected eye at baseline (or both eyes if the inflammation grade is the same in both eyes) and a 1-step decrease in the level of anterior chamber cells in the less severely affected eye at baseline

secondaryOutcomes.measure: Change in visual acuity measured by age-appropriate logarithm of the minimum angle of resolution test through week 24
secondaryOutcomes.description: Change in visual acuity from baseline

secondaryOutcomes.measure: Change in vitreous haze through week 24 in each affected eye
secondaryOutcomes.description: Change in vitreous haze from baseline

secondaryOutcomes.measure: Change in grade of flare in the anterior chamber through week 24 and week 284 in each affected eye
secondaryOutcomes.description: Change in grade of flare in the anterior chamber from baseline

secondaryOutcomes.measure: Change in overall uveitis-related disability: Change in Patient Uveitis-related Disease Activity through week 24
secondaryOutcomes.description: Change in Patient Uveitis-related Disease Activity from baseline

secondaryOutcomes.measure: Change in overall uveitis-related disability: Change in Patient Uveitis-related Improvement at week 12 and week 24
secondaryOutcomes.description: Change in Patient Uveitis-related Improvement from baseline

secondaryOutcomes.measure: Change in overall uveitis-related disability: Change in Patient Arthritis Disease Activity through week 24
secondaryOutcomes.description: Change in Patient Arthritis Disease Activity from baseline

secondaryOutcomes.measure: Change in overall uveitis-related disability: Change in Patient Arthritis Improvement at week 12 and week 24
secondaryOutcomes.description: Change in Patient Arthritis Improvement from baseline

secondaryOutcomes.measure: Change in overall uveitis-related disability: Change in Ophthalmologist Uveitis-related Disease Activity through week 24
secondaryOutcomes.description: Change in Ophthalmologist Uveitis-related Disease Activity from baseline

secondaryOutcomes.measure: Change in overall uveitis-related disability: Change in Ophthalmologist Uveitis-related Improvement at week 12 and week 24
secondaryOutcomes.description: Change in Ophthalmologist Uveitis-related Improvement from baseline

secondaryOutcomes.measure: Proportion of patients with inactive anterior uveitis (using SUN definition) in each affected eye through week 24 and week 284
secondaryOutcomes.description: Proportion of patients with inactive anterior uveitis according to SUN definition

secondaryOutcomes.measure: Time to inactive anterior uveitis disease (using SUN definition) in each affected eye
secondaryOutcomes.description: Time to inactive anterior uveitis disease according to SUN definition

secondaryOutcomes.measure: Proportion of patients who are able to taper concomitant corticosteroids
secondaryOutcomes.description: Proportion of patients who are able to taper concomitant corticosteroids

secondaryOutcomes.measure: Time to treatment response
secondaryOutcomes.description: Response is defined by a 2-step decrease in the level of inflammation (anterior chamber cells) or decrease to zero in the eye most severely affected at baseline

secondaryOutcomes.measure: Proportion of responders at week 284
secondaryOutcomes.description: Proportion of responders at week 284

secondaryOutcomes.measure: Pediatric American College of Rheumatology (PediACR) 30/50/70/90/100 response rates (for patients with JIA-uveitis)
secondaryOutcomes.description: PediACR 30/50/70/90/100 response rates

secondaryOutcomes.measure: Safety variables: Adverse events (AEs), including serious adverse events
secondaryOutcomes.description: Incidence of adverse events and serious adverse events

secondaryOutcomes.measure: Safety variables: Permanent discontinuation of investigational product due to AEs
secondaryOutcomes.description: Incidence of permanent discontinuation of investigational product due to adverse events

secondaryOutcomes.measure: Safety variables: Temporary interruption of investigational product
secondaryOutcomes.description: Incidence of temporary interruption of investigational product
